{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = The Sirian Experiments | title_orig = | image = Lessing SirianExperiments.jpg | caption = US first edition cover ([[Alfred A. Knopf]]) | author = [[Doris Lessing]] | cover_artist = Paul Gamarello | country = {{plainlist| *United States *United Kingdom }} | language = English | series = ''[[Canopus in Argos]]'' | genre = [[Novel]] ([[science fiction]]) | published = 1980 [[Alfred A. Knopf]], US, [[Jonathan Cape]], UK | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 331 | isbn = 0-394-51231-6 | isbn_note = (US)
0-224-01891-4 (UK) | dewey = 823/.914 | congress = PR6023.E833 S57 1981 | oclc = 5941786 | preceded_by = [[The Marriages Between Zones Three, Four and Five]] | followed_by = [[The Making of the Representative for Planet 8]] }} '''''The Sirian Experiments''''' is a 1980 science fiction novel by [[Doris Lessing]]. It is the third book in her five-book ''[[Canopus in Argos]]'' series{{cite web |url=http://www.dorislessing.org/canopusin.html |title=Canopus in Argos: Archives |work=dorislessing.org |accessdate=14 October 2008}} and continues the story of [[Earth]]'s [[evolution]], which has been manipulated from the beginning by advanced [[extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial civilisation]]s.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F05E5DE143BF930A25752C0A967948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Books of the Times: The Sirian Experiments |first=John |last=Leonard |authorlink=John Leonard (American critic) |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=13 January 1981}} It was first published in the United States in December 1980 by [[Alfred A. Knopf]], and in the United Kingdom in March 1981 by [[Jonathan Cape]]. The book was shortlisted for the [[List of winners and shortlisted authors of the Booker Prize|Booker Prize]] in 1981.{{cite web |url=http://themanbookerprize.com/fiction/1981 |title=The Man Booker Prize 1981 |work=[[Booker Prize]] |accessdate=25 June 2018}} ''The Sirian Experiments'' relates directly to the first book in this series, ''[[Shikasta]]'', which is the history of the planet Shikasta (an allegorical Earth) under the influence of three galactic empires, [[Canopus]], [[Sirius]] and their mutual enemy, Puttiora. ''Shikasta'' is told from the Canopean viewpoint.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorislessing.org/shikastaby.html |title=Shikasta |work=dorislessing.org |accessdate=14 October 2008}} ''The Sirian Experiments'' (subtitled ''The Report by Ambien II, of the Five'') tells the story of Shikasta from the Sirian point of view and describes the activities of Sirians on the planet and the strained relations of Sirius with Canopus.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorislessing.org/theexperiments.html |title=The Sirian Experiments |work=dorislessing.org |accessdate=14 October 2008}} Lessing stated in an [[afterword]] in the [[The Making of the Representative for Planet 8|next book]] in this series that ''The Sirian Experiments'' and ''[[The Making of the Representative for Planet 8]]'' were inspired by her 50-year fascination with the ill-fated [[Terra Nova Expedition|1910–13 Antarctic expedition]] of [[Robert Falcon Scott]].{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc="Afterword", p. 162}}{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C00E3DD1F38F93AA15752C0A964948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Books of the Times: The Making of the Representative for Planet 8 |first=Christopher |last=Lehmann-Haupt |authorlink=Christopher Lehmann-Haupt |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=29 January 1982}} ==Genre and reception== Because of its focus on characterisation and social/cultural issues, and the de-emphasis of technological details, ''The Sirian Experiments'' is not strictly science fiction but [[soft science fiction]], or "space fiction" as Lessing calls her ''Canopus in Argos'' series.{{sfn|Lessing|1994a|loc="Some Remarks", p. 8}} Robert Alter of ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested that this kind of writing belongs to a genre [[literary critic]] [[Northrop Frye]] called the "anatomy", which is "a combination of fantasy and morality" and that "presents us with a vision of the world in terms of a single intellectual pattern."{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B07E3D8173BF932A25752C0A967948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Doris Lessing in the Visionary Mode |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Robert |last=Alter |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=11 January 1981}} Lessing has stated that she has used this series as a vehicle to "put questions, both to myself and to others" and to "explore ideas and sociological possibilities."{{sfn|Lessing|1994b|loc="Preface", p. 11}} While Lessing's switch to "science fiction" in the late 1970s was not well received by all,{{cite web |url=http://mural.uv.es/vemivein/feminismcommunism.htm |title=Doris Lessing on Feminism, Communism and 'Space Fiction' |work=[[University of Valencia]] Press |first=Lesley |last=Hazelton |accessdate=14 October 2008}} the series in general has drawn positive criticism. Two reviews of ''The Sirian Experiments'' in ''The New York Times'' said that Lessing achieves "… a largeness of vision beyond the horizon of the conventional novel." and that it has "… some playful moments and some splendid ones. It is interesting, however, primarily because Doris Lessing wrote it." ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' on the other hand, which had spoken highly of the first two books in this series,{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,947537,00.html |title=Visit to a Small Planet |first=Paul |last=Gray |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=22 October 1979}}{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924037,00.html |title=Soul Mates |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |first=Paul |last=Gray |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=21 April 1980}} felt that this one "may be a small misstep on a long journey."{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,949106,00.html |title=More Lessing |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |first=Paul |last=Gray |accessdate=14 October 2008 | date=23 February 1981}} ==Plot== The Sirian Empire, centred in the [[Sirius]] star system, has advanced technology that made their citizens effectively immortal (barring accidents) and sophisticated machines that did almost everything for them. But this technology came at a price: many Sirians became afflicted with "the existentials", a debilitating malady that left them feeling worthless and with no reason to exist. To overcome this problem and give its people "something to do", Sirius embarked on a conquest of space and [[Colonisation|colonised]] many planets. But they also encroached on territory of the superior Canopean Empire that led to a costly war, which [[Canopus]] won. As a gesture of reconciliation, Canopus returned all the captured Sirian territory and invited Sirius to jointly colonise a new and promising planet called Rohanda (an allegorical [[Earth]]). Canopus took the northern continents and gave Sirius the southern continents. Ambien II, one of the Five who run the Sirian Colonial Service and also govern the Sirian Empire, represents Sirius on Rohanda. She sets in motion a series of [[biology|bio]]-[[Sociology|sociological]] and [[Genetics|genetic]] experiments where large numbers of primitive [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] from Sirian colonised planets are space-lifted to Rohanda and adapted there for work elsewhere in the Empire. In the north, Canopus nurtures Rohanda's bourgeoning [[humanoid]]s and accelerates their [[evolution]]. They also put a Lock on the planet that links it to the harmony and strength of the Canopean Empire. Canopus keeps Ambien II updated with reports of all their work, but she is suspicious of Sirius's former enemy, seeing them as a competitor rather than a partner, and is unable to correctly interpret them. Then an unforeseen "cosmic re-alignment" breaks the Lock and Shammat of the malicious Puttiora Empire begins exploiting the situation by corrupting Rohanda's Natives. Canopus, seeing Rohanda decline, renames the planet [[Shikasta]] (the stricken). Sirius, unconcerned about Canopus's troubles in the north, continue to refer to the planet as Rohanda. In an attempt to foster better relations with Sirius, Klorathy, a senior Canopean Colonial administrator, invites Ambien II to observe events in their territory. Ambien II, eager to learn more about Canopus, agrees. As Rohanda evolves and civilisations come and go, Ambien II and Klorathy meet several times to watch Rohanda's degeneration. Canopus does what it can to help communities, but with Shammat's evil and a broken Lock, they make little progress. From time to time Klorathy requests Ambien II's help and while working on the planet, she meets Nasar, another Canopean official. She also encounters Tafta, the Shammat commander on Rohanda, and at one point nearly succumbs to his corruption. Ambien II eventually abandons the Sirian Experiments in the south when they are overrun by Shammat. The Five want her to abandon Rohanda altogether, but she has become too attached to the planet and is warming to Canopus and seeing the error of her (and Sirius's) ways. The Five question her ties to their former enemy, but when she tries to explain herself, they do not hear what she is saying, just as she initially could not hear what Canopus was saying. The Five then send her to Planet 13 on "corrective exile" to write a report on what has happened (this book). When she later releases the report, the Five issues a statement denying the authenticity of Ambien II's work. ==Characters== ;Sirius *The Five – peer group of five senior administrators of the Sirian Colonial Service *Ambien II – one of the Five, Sirian representative to Rohanda ;Canopus *Klorathy – senior Canopean Colonial administrator *Nasar – permanent official on Rohanda ;Shammat *Tafta – Shammat representative to Rohanda ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Works cited== *{{cite book | last = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = Doris Lessing | title = Shikasta | origyear = 1979 | year = 1994a | publisher = Flamingo | location = London | isbn = 0-00-712776-6 | ref = harv}} *{{cite book | last = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = Doris Lessing | title = The Sirian Experiments | origyear = 1980 | year = 1994b | publisher = Flamingo | location = London | isbn = 0-00-654721-4 | ref = harv}} *{{cite book | last = Lessing | first = Doris | authorlink = Doris Lessing | title = The Making of the Representative for Planet 8 | origyear = 1982 | year = 1994c | publisher = Flamingo | location = London | isbn = 0-00-654718-4 | ref = harv}} == Further reading == *{{cite book | last = Fahim | first = Shadia S. | authorlink = | title = Doris Lessing: Sufi Equilibrium and the Form of the Novel | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan/St. Martins Press | year = 1995 | location = Basingstoke, UK/New York, NY | isbn = 0-312-10293-3}} * {{cite book | last = Galin | first = Müge | authorlink = | title = Between East and West: Sufism in the Novels of Doris Lessing | publisher = State University of New York Press | year = 1997 | location = Albany, NY | isbn = 0-7914-3383-8}} ==External links== *[http://www.dorislessing.org/theexperiments.html ''The Sirian Experiments''] at dorislessing.org. * {{isfdb title|8283}} *[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,949106,00.html "More Lessing"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' review. *[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B07E3D8173BF932A25752C0A967948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all "Doris Lessing in the Visionary Mode"]. ''[[The New York Times]]'' book review. *[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F05E5DE143BF930A25752C0A967948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all "Books of the Times"]. ''[[The New York Times]]'' book review. {{Doris Lessing}} {{Portal bar|Literature}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sirian Experiments, The}} [[Category:1980 British novels]] [[Category:1980 science fiction novels]] [[Category:Canopus in fiction]] [[Category:Novels by Doris Lessing]] [[Category:British science fiction novels]] [[Category:Alfred A. Knopf books]] [[Category:Jonathan Cape books]] [[Category:Sequel novels]] [[Category:Sirius in fiction]] [[Category:Social science fiction]]

page.title: Toxicology of red imported fire ant venom

revision.text:
The '''toxicology of fire ant venom''' is relatively well studied. The [[venom]] plays a central role in the biology of [[Red imported fire ant]]s, such as in capturing prey,<ref name=Laietal2012>{{cite journal |last1=Lai |first1=Li-Chuan |last2=Kuo |first2=Tai-Chih |last3=Huang |first3=Rong-Nan |last4=Wu |first4=Wen-Jer |title=The Insecticidal Activities of Fire Ant (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) Venoms Against ''Plutella xylostella'' (Lepidoptera: Plutellidae) Larvae |journal=Journal of Economic Entomology |date=1 October 2012 |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=1591–1596 |doi=10.1603/EC12075}}</ref> and in defending itself from competitors,<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |last1=Greenberg |first1=Les |last2=Kabashima |first2=John N. |last3=Allison |first3=Clinton J. |last4=Rust |first4=Michael K. |last5=Klotz |first5=John H. |last6=Hurvois |first6=Jean-Pierre |last7=Paine |first7=Timothy D. |title=Lethality of Red Imported Fire Ant Venom to Argentine Ants and Other Ant Species |journal=Annals of the Entomological Society of America |date=1 November 2008 |volume=101 |issue=6 |pages=1162–1168 |doi=10.1603/0013-8746-101.6.1162}}</ref> assailants,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Haight |first1=K. L. |title=Defensiveness of the fire ant, Solenopsis invicta, is increased during colony rafting |journal=Insectes Sociaux |date=February 2006 |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=32–36 |doi=10.1007/s00040-005-0832-y}}</ref> and diseases.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Obin |first1=Martin S. |last2=Vander Meer |first2=Robert K. |title=Gaster flagging by fire ants (Solenopsis spp.): Functional significance of venom dispersal behavior |journal=Journal of Chemical Ecology |date=December 1985 |volume=11 |issue=12 |pages=1757–1768 |doi=10.1007/BF01012125}}</ref> Some 14 million people are stung annually in the United States,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Taber |first1=Stephen |title=Fire ants |date=Aug 2000 |publisher=Texas A & M University Press |isbn=0890969450 |pages=308 |edition=1st |url=https://www.amazon.com/Fire-Ants-Stephen-Welton-Taber/dp/0890969450}}</ref> suffering reactions that vary from mild discomfort, to pustule formation, swelling,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hoffman |first1=Donald R |title=Ant venoms |journal=Current Opinion in Allergy and Clinical Immunology |date=August 2010 |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=342–346 |doi=10.1097/ACI.0b013e328339f325}}</ref> and in rare cases, systemic reactions followed by anaphylactic shock.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Stafford |first1=Chester T |title=Hypersensitivity to Fire Ant Venom |journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology |date=August 1996 |volume=77 |issue=2 |pages=87–99 |doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)63493-X}}</ref> Fire ant venoms are mainly composed (>95%) of a complex mixture of insoluble alkaloids added to a watery solution of toxic proteins.<ref>Fox E.G.P. (2016) Venom Toxins of Fire Ants. In: Gopalakrishnakone P., Calvete J. (eds) Venom Genomics and Proteomics. Toxinology. Springer, Dordrecht</ref> For the [[Red imported fire ant]] ''Solenopsis invicta'' Buren there are currently 46 described proteins,<ref name=Pintoetal2012>{{cite journal |last1=Pinto |first1=José R. A. |last2=Fox |first2=Eduardo G. P. |last3=Saidemberg |first3=Daniel M. |last4=Santos |first4=Lucilene D. |last5=da Silva Menegasso |first5=Anally R. |last6=Costa-Manso |first6=Eliúde |last7=Machado |first7=Ednildo A. |last8=Bueno |first8=Odair C. |last9=Palma |first9=Mario S. |title=Proteomic View of the Venom from the Fire Ant Buren |journal=Journal of Proteome Research |date=22 August 2012 |volume=11 |issue=9 |pages=4643–4653 |doi=10.1021/pr300451g}}</ref> of which four are well-characterised as potent [[allergen]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hoffman |first1=DR |last2=Dove |first2=DE |last3=Jacobson |first3=RS |title=Allergens in Hymenoptera venom. XX. Isolation of four allergens from imported fire ant (Solenopsis invicta) venom. |journal=The Journal of allergy and clinical immunology |date=November 1988 |volume=82 |issue=5 Pt 1 |pages=818–27 |pmid=3192865}}</ref>
==Venom== {{see also|Solenopsin}} [[File:Solenopsin.svg|thumb|[[Solenopsin]], one of the components of the venom]] Venom plays an important role in the biology of fire ants, being used to capture prey items,<ref name=Laietal2012 /> nest defense,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and antimicrobial action.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jouvenaz |first1=D. P. |last2=Blum |first2=M. S. |last3=MacConnell |first3=J. G. |title=Antibacterial Activity of Venom Alkaloids from the Imported Fire Ant, Solenopsis invicta Buren1 |journal=Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy |date=1 October 1972 |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=291–293 |doi=10.1128/AAC.2.4.291}}</ref> On average, however, a worker stores very little venom (only about 0.5 µg at any given time).<ref name="Gebel_2012">{{cite news|last1=Gebel|first1=E.|title=Proteins Revealed In Fire Ant Venom|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/90/web/2012/08/Proteins-Revealed-Fire-Ant-Venom.html|accessdate=8 August 2016|work=Chemical & Engineering News|date=20 August 2012|issn=0009-2347}}</ref> Newborn workers contain little to no venom within their reservoirs, but workers that are only one-day old can produce 1.17 µg/day. However, workers that are 15 days old only produce 0.3 µg/day. Workers deliver 0.66 nl of venom when they sting, which amounts to 3.1% of their supply. Older workers deliver less venom when they sting, but middle-aged workers and nest-defenders deliver much higher quantities.<ref name="Haight_Tschinkel_2003">{{cite journal|last1=Haight|first1=K.L.|last2=Tschinkel|first2=W.R.|title=Patterns of venom synthesis and use in the fire ant, ''Solenopsis invicta''|journal=Toxicon|date=2003|volume=42 |issue=6|pages=673–682 |doi=10.1016/j.toxicon.2003.09.005 |pmid=14602123|url=http://www.bio.fsu.edu/~tschink/publications/2003-1.pdf}}</ref> Like all fire ant species, venom is secreted by the venom gland and is stored in the poison sac.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Paterson Fox |first1=Eduardo Gonçalves |last2=Correa Bueno |first2=Odair |last3=Yabuki |first3=Antônio Teruyoshi |last4=jesus |first4=Carlos Massuretti de |last5=Solis |first5=Daniel Russ |last6=Rossi |first6=Mônica Lanzoni |last7=Nogueira |first7=Neusa de Lima |title=General Morphology and Ultrastructure of the Venom Apparatus and Convoluted Gland of the Fire Ant, |journal=Journal of Insect Science |date=March 2010 |volume=10 |issue=24 |pages=1–11 |doi=10.1673/031.010.2401}}</ref> When in use, it is ejected through the stinger's main duct. Capacity is between 20 and 40 nl, but this depends on the worker's size.{{sfn|Tschinkel|2006|p=365}} The American entomologist [[Justin O. Schmidt]] described it as being "sharp, sudden, mildly alarming", therefore ranking at "1" in the [[Schmidt sting pain index]], a [[pain scale]] which ranks the pain intensity of an insect's sting from 0 to 4.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Hemolytic activities of stinging insect venoms|first=J.O.|last=Schmidt |first2=M.S.|last2=Blum |first3=W.L.|last3=Overal|journal=Archives of Insect Biochemistry and Physiology|volume=1|issue=2|pages=155–160 |date=1983|doi=10.1002/arch.940010205}}</ref>
Over 95% of the venom components are water-[[Solubility|insoluble]] [[piperidine]] [[alkaloid]]s. Piperidines include [[Solenopsin|''trans''-2-methyl-6-n-undecylpiperidine]]s, ''trans''-2-methyl-6-n-tridecylpiperidine, ''trans''-2-methyl-6-(''cis''-4-tridecenyl) piperidines, ''trans''-2-methyl-6-n-pentadecylpiperidine, ''trans''-2-methyl-6-(''cis''-6-pentadecenyl)piperidine and 2,6-dialkylpiperidines (the ants' venom is dominated by the ''trans''- stereoisomers of this specific ingredient).<ref name="Buren_1972">{{cite journal|last1=Buren|first1=W.F.|title=Revisionary studies on the taxonomy of the imported fire ants|journal=Journal of the Georgia Entomological Society|date=1972|volume=7|pages=1–26|doi=10.5281/zenodo.27055|url=https://zenodo.org/record/27055/files/6818.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jouvenaz|first1=D.P.|last2=Blum |first2=M.S.|last3=MacConnell|first3=J.G.|title=Antibacterial activity of venom alkaloids from the imported fire ant, ''Solenopsis invicta'' Buren|journal=Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy|date=1972|volume=2|issue=4 |pages=291–293|doi=10.1128/AAC.2.4.291 |pmid=4670503|pmc=444309}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chen|first1=L.|last2=Fadamiro|first2=H.Y.|title=Re-investigation of venom chemistry of ''Solenopsis'' fire ants. II. Identification of novel alkaloids in ''S. invicta''|journal=Toxicon|date=2009|volume=53 |issue=5|pages=479–486|doi=10.1016/j.toxicon.2009.01.016|pmid=19673093}}</ref> ''trans''-2-Methyl-6-n-undecylpiperidine (solenopsin) has been shown to have [[Cytotoxicity|cytotoxic]], [[Hemolysis|hemolytic]], [[Necrosis|necrotic]], insecticidal, [[antibacterial]], antifungal, and anti-[[HIV]] properties.<ref name="Howell_et_al_2005">{{cite journal|last1=Howell|first1=G.|last2=Butler|first2=J. |last3=Deshazo|first3=R.D. |last4=Farley|first4=J.M. |last5=Liu|first5=H.L. |last6=Nanayakkara|first6=N.P.|last7=Yates|first7=A. |last8=Yi|first8=G.B.|last9=Rockhold |first9=R.W.|title=Cardiodepressant and neurologic actions of ''Solenopsis invicta'' (imported fire ant) venom alkaloids|journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology|date=2005|volume=94|issue=3|pages=380–386 |pmid=15801250|doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)60991-X}}</ref> As well as that, the alkaloid has shown [[Angiogenesis|antiangiogenic]] activity.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Arbiser|first1=J.L.|last2=Kau |first2=T.|last3=Konar|first3=M.|last4=Narra |first4=K.|last5=Ramchandran|first5=R. |last6=Summers|first6=S.A.|last7=Vlahos |first7=C.J.|last8=Ye|first8=K.|last9=Perry|first9=B.N.|last10=Matter |first10=W. |last11=Fischl |first11=A. |last12=Cook |first12=J.|last13=Silver |first13=P.A. |last14=Bain|first14=J. |last15=Cohen|first15=P. |last16=Whitmire |first16=D. |last17=Furness |first17=S.|last18=Govindarajan|first18=B.|last19=Bowen|first19=J.P.|title=Solenopsin, the alkaloidal component of the fire ant (''Solenopsis invicta''), is a naturally occurring inhibitor of phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase signaling and angiogenesis |journal=Blood|date=2007|volume=109|issue=2|pages=560–565|doi=10.1182/blood-2006-06-029934|pmid=16990598 |pmc=1785094}}</ref> These components are responsible for the formation of [[Urticaria|hives]], and also for the development of sterile [[Cutaneous condition#Primary lesions|pustule]]s on areas where the ant has stung.<ref name="Hoffman_2010">{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman|first1=D.R.|title=Ant venoms |journal=Current Opinion in Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=2010|volume=10|pages=342–346|url=http://antgenomes.org/publications/hoffman2010antVenoms.pdf|doi=10.1097/aci.0b013e328339f325}}</ref> Experiments indicate that the [[median lethal dose]] (LD<sub>50</sub>) on tested female rats is 0.36 mg/kg.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Alley|first1=E.G.|title=The use of mirex in control of the imported fire ant|journal=Journal of Environment Quality|date=1973|volume=2|issue=1|pages=52–61|doi=10.2134/jeq1973.00472425000200010005x}}</ref>
Approximately 46 proteins have been identified in the red imported fire ant's venom,<ref name=Pintoetal2012 /> although scientists have long believed the venom only contained alkaloids.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=BLUM |first1=MS |last2=WALKER |first2=JR |last3=CALLAHAN |first3=PS |last4=NOVAK |first4=AF |title=Chemical, insecticidal and antibiotic properties of fire ant venom. |journal=Science |date=8 August 1958 |volume=128 |issue=3319 |pages=306–7 |pmid=13568785}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Baer |first1=Harold |last2=Liu |first2=T.-Y. |last3=Anderson |first3=Martha C. |last4=Blum |first4=Murray |last5=Schmid |first5=William H. |last6=James |first6=Frank J. |title=Protein components of fire ant venom (Solenopsis invicta) |journal=Toxicon |date=January 1979 |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=397–405 |doi=10.1016/0041-0101(79)90267-8}}</ref> This assumption was mostly due to the difficulties in obtaining sufficient venom for analysis because of its the low protein content, which is only 0.1% of the venom's total weight.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fox |first1=Eduardo G P |last2=Solis |first2=Daniel R |last3=Santos |first3=Lucilene D R |last4=Pinto |first4=Jose Roberto |last5=Menegasso |first5=Anally R S |last6=Silva |first6=Rafael CMC |last7=Palma |first7=Mario S |last8=Bueno |first8=Odair C |last9=Machado |first9=Ednildo A |title=A simple, rapid method for the extraction of whole fire ant venom (Insecta: Formicidae: Solenopsis) |journal=Toxicon |date=April 2013 |volume=65 |pages=5–8 |doi=10.1016/j.toxicon.2012.12.009}}</ref>
These proteins are experimentally suggested to directly account for the [[Anaphylaxis|anaphylactic]] reactions seen in humans sensitive to the venom.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zamith-Miranda |first1=Daniel |last2=Fox |first2=Eduardo G. P. |last3=Monteiro |first3=Ana Paula |last4=Gama |first4=Diogo |last5=Poublan |first5=Luiz E. |last6=de Araujo |first6=Almair Ferreira |last7=Araujo |first7=Maria F. C. |last8=Atella |first8=Georgia C. |last9=Machado |first9=Ednildo A. |last10=Diaz |first10=Bruno L. |title=The allergic response mediated by fire ant venom proteins |journal=Scientific Reports |date=26 September 2018 |volume=8 |issue=1 |doi=10.1038/s41598-018-32327-z}}</ref> Whilst including a number of neurotoxins and potential allergens, not all of these proteins are involved with venom function.<ref name=Pintoetal2012 /> At least four protein [[allergen]]s have been characterised, named Sol i 1-4. Of these, Sol i 3, is part of the antigen 5 family, and Sol i 1 is a [[phospholipase]] A<small>1</small>B; Sol i 1 shows a close relation with wasp venom [[phospholipase]]s.<ref name="Hoffman_2010"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman|first1=D.R.|last2=Sakell|first2=R.H.|last3=Schmidt|first3=M.|title=Sol i 1, the phospholipase allergen of imported fire ant venom |journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=2005 |volume=115|issue=3 |pages=611–616 |doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2004.11.020 |pmid=15753912}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman |first1=D.R. |last2=Dove|first2=D.E.|last3=Jacobson |first3=R.S.|title=Allergens in Hymenoptera venom. XX. Isolation of four allergens from imported fire ant (''Solenopsis invicta'') venom|journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=1988 |volume=82|issue=5 Pt 1|pages=818–827|doi=10.1016/0091-6749(88)90084-X|pmid=3192865}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman|first1=D.R.|title=Allergens in Hymenoptera venom XXIV: the amino acid sequences of imported fire ant venom allergens Sol i II, Sol i III, and Sol i IV|journal=The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology |date=1993 |volume=91 |issue=1 Pt 1|pages=71–78|doi=10.1016/0091-6749(93)90298-T|pmid=8423273}}</ref> Sol i 2 and 4 are unique, odorant-binding proteins of poorly understood function. Other proteins found in the venom may benefit the colony; some of these proteins can kill off bacteria, which may explain why workers spray venom around their nests by vibrating their gasters. Other proteins also bind pheromones which may assist a worker to lay chemical trails to communicate with other nestmates.<ref name="Gebel_2012"/><ref name=Pintoetal2012 /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Obin|first1=M.S.|last2=Vander Meer|first2=R.K.|title=Gaster flagging by fire ants (''Solenopsis'' spp.): Functional significance of venom dispersal behavior|journal=Journal of Chemical Ecology|date=1985|volume=11|issue=12|pages=1757–1768|doi=10.1007/BF01012125|pmid=24311339}}</ref>
==Incidence==
In the United States, more than 40 million people live in areas infested with fire ant populations and 14 million people are stung by them annually. A quarter of all victims stung by red imported fire ants are expected to develop sensitivity to the venom, and approximately 6,000 will suffer anaphylaxis.{{sfn|Taber|2000|p=130}} 51% of people who relocated themselves to infested areas report getting stung within three weeks after arrival.<ref name="Tracy_et_al_1995">{{cite journal|last1=Tracy |first1=J.M.|last2=Demain|first2=J.G. |last3=Quinn|first3=J.M. |last4=Hoffman |first4=D.R.|last5=Goetz|first5=D.W. |last6=Freeman|first6=T.M.|title=The natural history of exposure to the imported fire ant (''Solenopsis invicta'') |journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=1995|volume=95 |issue=4|pages=824–828 |doi=10.1016/S0091-6749(95)70125-7|pmid=7722162}}</ref> In a survey conducted in [[South Carolina]], 33,000 people (or 94 per 10,000 population) received medical attention due to red imported fire ants, and 660 people (1.9 per 10 000 population) were treated for anaphylaxis.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Caldwell|first1=S.T.|last2=Schuman|first2=S.H.|last3=Simpson|first3=W.M. Jr.|title=Fire ants: a continuing community health threat in South Carolina|journal=Journal of the South Carolina Medical Association (1975)|date=1999 |volume=95 |issue=6 |pages=231–235|pmid=10389385}}</ref> In Texas, 79% of participants in a survey stated they had been stung by red imported fire ants, while 20% had not. 61% of West Texans state they had been stung by the ants before, compared to 90% in central Texas, 89% in east Texas, 86% in the gulf coastal regions, 78% in the south and 72% in the north.<ref name="CABI_2014">{{cite web|title=''Solenopsis invicta'' (red imported fire ant)|url=http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/50569|work=Invasive Species Compendium|publisher=CABI|accessdate=12 April 2016|date=2014}}</ref> In separate survey, 87% of individuals classed their reactions as mild, 12% as moderate and 1% as severe.<ref name="Adams_Lofgren_1981">{{cite journal|last1=Adams |first1=C.T.|last2=Lofgren|first2=C.S.|title=Red imported fire ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae): frequency of sting attacks on residents of Sumter County, Georgia|journal=Journal of Medical Entomology|date=1981|volume=18|issue=5|pages=378–382|doi=10.1093/jmedent/18.5.378 |pmid=7299792}}</ref> In Australia, 64,000 homes are within red imported fire ant infested areas, and 140,000 consultations and 3,000 anaphylactic reaction cases are predicted every year by 2030 if government efforts to eradicate the ant fail.<ref name="Solley_et_al_2002">{{cite journal|last1=Solley|first1=G.O.|last2=Vanderwoude|first2=C.|last3=Knight|first3=G.K.|title=Anaphylaxis due to red imported fire ant sting|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=2002|volume=176|issue=11|pages=521–523|pmid=12064982}}</ref> A survey conducted in China shows that one-third of participants in infested areas were victims of red imported fire ant stings.<ref name="Xu_et_al_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Xu|first1=Y.|last2=Huang|first2=J.|last3=Zhou|first3=A.|last4=Zeng|first4=L.|title=Prevalence of ''Solenopsis invicta'' (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) venom allergic reactions in mainland China|journal=The Florida Entomologist|date=2012 |volume=95|issue=4 |pages=961–965 |doi=10.1653/024.095.0421}}</ref>
Studies suggest that the rate of systemic reactions to stings may be associated with seasonal variations in the venom's potency. 51% of allergic reactions occurred in summer, and 19% in spring. However, A survey reported a higher incidence during spring (39.9%) than summer (31.9%).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hannan|first1=C. Jr.|last2=Stafford |first2=C.|last3=Rhoades |first3=R.|last4=Wray|first4=B. |last5=Baer |first5=H. |last6=Anderson |first6=M.|title=Seasonal variation in antigens of the imported fire ant ''Solenopsis invicta''|journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=1986 |volume=78|issue=2 |pages=331–336|doi=10.1016/S0091-6749(86)80085-9|pmid=3734284}}</ref> Younger people, usually those under 20 years, experience the highest rate of sting attacks (50%), but the rate declines with older people. Among men and women, the rate varies as some studies report more women being attacked than men and vice versa.<ref name="Adams_Lofgren_1981"/><ref name="Xu_et_al_2012"/> Deaths from red imported fire ant stings are rare, but may become common the more the ant spreads. Many cases have also been reported in the past.<ref name="Prahlow_Barnard_1998">{{cite journal|last1=Prahlow |first1=J.A. |last2=Barnard |first2=J.J. |title=Fatal anaphylaxis due to fire ant stings|journal=The American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology |date=1998 |volume=19|issue=2|pages=137–142 |doi=10.1097/00000433-199806000-00007|pmid=9662108}}</ref> It is reported that more than 80 deaths have been recorded; of these, 22 cases were recorded in Florida and 19 in Texas. However, when duplicate reports are excluded, four deaths were recorded in Alabama, 10 in Florida, two in Georgia and Louisiana, and 14 in Texas.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rhoades|first1=R.B. |last2=Stafford |first2=C.T. |last3=James|first3=F.K.|title=Survey of fatal anaphylactic reactions to imported fire ant stings |journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology |date=1989 |volume=84|issue=2|pages=159–162 |doi=10.1016/0091-6749(89)90319-9 |pmid=2760357}}</ref><ref name="deShazo_et_al_1999">{{cite journal |last1=deShazo|first1=R.D. |last2=Williams|first2=D.F. |last3=Moak |first3=E.S. |title=Fire ant attacks on residents in health care facilities: a report of two cases|journal=Annals of Internal Medicine |date=1999 |volume=131 |issue=6|pages=424–429 |pmid=10498558|doi=10.7326/0003-4819-131-6-199909210-00005}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Lockey |first1=R.F.|last2=Ledford |first2=D.K.|title=Allergens and Allergen Immunotherapy: Subcutaneous, Sublingual, and Oral |date=2014|publisher=CRC Press, Taylor & Francis Group|location=Boca Raton, Florida|isbn=978-1-84214-574-6|pages=409–410|edition=5th}}</ref> People can be educated and be made aware of the dangers of red imported fire ants.<ref name="NPS_2010">{{cite web|title=Integrated Pest Management Manual: Fireants|url=http://www.nature.nps.gov/biology/ipm/manual/fireants.cfm|work=National Park Service|publisher=United States Department of the Interior|date=2010|accessdate=21 August 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922170548/http://www.nature.nps.gov/biology/ipm/manual/fireants.cfm|archivedate=22 September 2016}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms==
[[File:FireAntBite.jpg|thumb|Formation of pustules on a human leg]]
Reactions seen in humans vary; some are hypersensitive to venom while others show resilience. [[Hypersensitivity]] can be attributed to certain medical problems such as heart conditions or diabetes. Bacterial infections attributed to sting injuries also pose a problem and may require further medical attention. Most humans can withstand many stings, but others may suffer from severe reactions such as anaphylaxis.<ref name="Drees_2002">{{cite web|last1=Drees|first1=B.M.|title=Medical problems and treatment considerations for the red imported fire ant|url=https://fireant.tamu.edu/files/2011/12/FAPFS023_2002rev_Medical.pdf|work=Texas Imported Fire Ant Research and Management Project|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=23 August 2016|date=2002}}</ref>
People who are stung by red imported fire ants may experience intense local burning or flare-ups, followed by reddening of the skin at the sting site. This area will swell into a bump, hive or [[Cutaneous condition#Primary lesions|vesicle]] within 20 minutes. White fluid-filled sterile pustules begin to form within hours or days after being stung.<ref name="Drees_2002"/><ref name="Xu_et_al_2012"/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Schneiderman|first1=P. |last2=Grossman|first2=M.|title=A Clinician's Guide to Dermatologic Differential Diagnosis, Volume 1: The Text |date=2006|publisher=CRC Press |location=New York|isbn=978-0-203-09052-7|page=93}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Potiwat |first1=R.|last2=Sitcharungsi |first2=R.|title=Ant allergens and hypersensitivity reactions in response to ant stings|journal=Asian Pacific Journal of Allergy and Immunology |date=2015|volume=33|issue=4|pages=267–275|pmid=26708389}}</ref> Pustules on the skin remain for a couple of days, and may become infected which would require medical attention. In most cases, pustules dry up in a matter of weeks and leave brown scars that either remain for several months or become permanent.<ref name="Drees_2002"/> The formation of pustules occurs in almost every person stung by the ants. In one study, 96% of participants reported the formation of pustules, whereas 2% reported large local reactions.<ref name="Tracy_et_al_1995"/> Between 17% to 56% of people stung develop venom-specific [[Immunoglobulin E|IgE]]. Many of them will experience pruritic lumps around areas where the ants stung, known as late-phase responses or cutaneous allergic reactions.<ref name="deShazo_et_al_1999"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stafford|first1=C.T.|title=Fire ant allergy|journal=Allergy Proceedings|date=1992|volume=13|issue=1|pages=11–16|pmid=1577260|doi=10.2500/108854192778878971}}</ref><ref name="Caro_et_al_1957">{{cite journal|last1=Caro|first1=M.R.|last2=Derbes|first2=V.J.|last3=Jung|first3=R.|title=Skin responses to the sting of the imported fire ant (''Solenopsis Saevissima'')|journal=Archives of Dermatology|date=1957|volume=75|issue=4|pages=475–488|doi=10.1001/archderm.1957.01550160001001|pmid=13410107}}</ref>
Pustule formation can only be prevented if the ants are removed before they have a chance to sting. Once venom has been injected, pustules will form and no form of treatment will prevent them from occurring. Medications such as antibiotics, [[2,4-Dinitrophenylhydrazine|diphenylhydrazines]], [[epinephrine]]s or [[topical steroids]] will not affect pustular reactions.<ref name="Drees_2002"/><ref name="Caro_et_al_1957"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Parrino|first1=J.|last2=Kandawalla|first2=N.M.|last3=Lockey |first3=R.F.|title=Treatment of local skin response to imported fire ant sting |journal=Southern Medical Journal|date=1981 |volume=74 |issue=11 |pages=1361–1364 |pmid=7302637 |doi=10.1097/00007611-198111000-00017}}</ref>
Anaphylaxis occurs in 0.6 to 6% of people who have been stung by the ants, and it can be fatal if left untreated.<ref name="Prahlow_Barnard_1998"/><ref name="deShazo_et_al_1999"/> Typical symptoms of anaphylaxis include dizziness, headaches, fever, severe chest pain, nausea, severe sweating, low blood pressure, loss of breath, serious swelling, and slurred speech.<ref name="Drees_2002"/><ref name="Xu_et_al_2012"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/insects/fireants.html|title=Insects and Scorpions – Fire Ants |accessdate=11 April 2008|date=2008|work=The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922153947/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/insects/fireants.html|archivedate=22 September 2016}}</ref> One case reports a victim feeling strong [[vertigo]] 5 to 10 minutes after being stung, followed by glassy eyes, dry mouth, paleness, unconsciousness and severe cramps on the sting sites.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haddad Junior|first1=V.|last2=Larsson |first2=C.E.|title=Anaphylaxis caused by stings from the ''Solenopsis invicta'', lava-pés ant or red imported fire ant|journal=Anais Brasileiros de Dermatologia|date=2015|volume=90|issue=3 |pages=22–25|doi=10.1590/abd1806-4841.20153420 |pmid=26312665|pmc=4540499}}</ref> In addition, [[Peripheral neuropathy|neuropathy]], seizures (even without any evidence of prior systemic reactions), [[Stroke|cerebrovascular accidents]], and [[nephrotic syndrome]] have been associated with red imported fire ant stings.<ref name="Drees_2002"/><ref name="deShazo_et_al_1999"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Candiotti|first1=Keith A.|last2=Lamas|first2=Ana M.|title=Adverse neurologic reactions to the sting of the imported fire ant |journal=International Archives of Allergy and Immunology|date=1993|volume=102|issue=4 |pages=417–420 |doi=10.1159/000236592 |pmid=8241804}}</ref> A series of [[neurotoxin]]s have been identified in red imported fire ant venom, which may explain why some victims experience hallucinations after they have been stung.<ref name="Gebel_2012"/>
==Treatment==
{{main|Allergen immunotherapy}} [[File:Adrenalina.jpg|thumb|left|Adrenaline (also called epinephrine) can quickly reverse the adverse events of dyspnoea and hypotension]]
It is suggested that a conservative approach be used when treating sting injuries; specifically, the kind of treatment used should be based on the symptoms. For minor sting injuries, with symptoms only including pustule formations and pain, over-the-counter products are available to prevent infection. Ants should be removed by washing the area with antiseptic soap, and itchiness. It is rare for ant sting sites to become infected, so the use of antibiotic prophylaxis is not always required.<ref name="Drees_2002"/><ref name="Pesek_Lockey_2013">{{cite journal|last1=Pesek|first1=R.D.|last2=Lockey|first2=R.F.|title=Management of insect sting hypersensitivity: an update|journal=Allergy, Asthma & Immunology Research|date=2013|volume=5|issue=3|pages=129–137|doi=10.4168/aair.2013.5.3.129|pmid=23638310|pmc=3636446}}</ref>
Victims who show signs of anaphylaxis are treated with antihistamines, [[epinephrine]]s, and parenteral corticosteroids.<ref name="deShazo_et_al_1999"/> Epinephrine is the first product for use to treat systemic allergic responses, particularly if a patient is experiencing [[dyspnoea]] or [[hypotension]] because it is capable of reversing adverse events quickly and is very safe to use. It is recommended that people who have suffered from anaphylaxis carry an [[epinephrine autoinjector]] (EpiPen), should dyspnoea or hypotension begin to occur.<ref name="Solley_et_al_2002"/>
Whole body extract immunotherapy (WBE) to treat victims of anaphylaxis has been in use since 1973.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Moffitt |first1=J.E. |last2=Barker|first2=J.R.|last3=Stafford |first3=C.T.|title=Management of imported fire ant allergy: Results of a survey |journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology |date=1997|volume=79|issue=2|pages=125–130 |doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)63098-0 |pmid=9291416}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Triplett|first1=R.F.|title=Sensitivity to the imported fire ant: successful treatment with immunotherapy |journal=Southern Medical Journal|date=1973|volume=66|issue=4|pages=477–480 |pmid=4708246 |doi=10.1097/00007611-197304000-00019}}</ref> Anyone who has a suspected allergy to the venom is redirected to an allergist for assessment.<ref name="Drees_2002"/> The treatment uses the entire body of the ant and not just the venom, and unlike fire ant venom immunotherapy (which is occasionally used), WBE contains venom proteins.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nordvall|first1=S.L.|last2=Johansson|first2=S.G.|last3=Ledford|first3=D.K.|last4=Lockey|first4=R.F.|title=Allergens of the imported fire ant.|journal=The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=1988|volume=82|issue=4|pages=567–576 |pmid=3171000|doi=10.1016/0091-6749(88)90966-9}}</ref> To reduce a patient's sensitivity to the venom, gradual increases of dose extracts are injected into the body.<ref>{{cite web|title=Types of Allergies: Insect Sting Allergy|url=http://acaai.org/allergies/types/insect-sting-allergies|publisher=American College of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref> WBE immunotherapy appears to be very effective in preventing systemic reactions; in one study of participants who completed WBE immunotherapy, two out of fifteen participants suffered from allergic reactions upon being stung 18 months after immunotherapy.<ref name="Pesek_Lockey_2013"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Freeman|first1=T.|last2=Hylander|first2=R. |last3=Ortiz|first3=A.|last4=Martin|first4=M.|title=Imported fire ant immunotherapy: Effectiveness of whole body extracts|journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=1992|volume=90|issue=2 |pages=210–215|doi=10.1016/0091-6749(92)90073-B|pmid=1500625}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Paull|first1=B.R.|title=Imported fire ant allergy. Perspectives on diagnosis and treatment|journal=Postgraduate Medicine|date=1984|volume=76|issue=1|pages=155–162|doi=10.1080/00325481.1984.11698672|pmid=6739381}}</ref> As mentioned, fire ant venom immunotherapy is occasionally used, and studies show it can reduce the risk of systemic reactions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stafford|first1=C.T|title=Hypersensitivity to fire ant venom|journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology|date=1996|volume=77|issue=2|pages=87–99|doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)63493-X|pmid=8760773}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Letz|first1=A.G.|last2=Quinn|first2=J.M.|title=Frequency of imported fire ant stings in patients receiving immunotherapy|journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology|date=2009|volume=102|issue=4 |pages=303–307 |doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)60335-3 |pmid=19441601}}</ref> In fact, another study claims that fire ant venom immunotherapy is more effective than WBE immunotherapy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hunt|first1=K.J.|last2=Valentine |first2=M.D.|last3=Sobotka|first3=A.K.|last4=Benton|first4=A.W.|last5=Amodio|first5=F.J.|last6=Lichtenstein|first6=L.M.|title=A controlled trial of immunotherapy in insect hypersensitivity|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|date=1978|volume=299|issue=4|pages=157–161|doi=10.1056/NEJM197807272990401|pmid=78446}}</ref> Fire ant venom immunotherapy is not recommended for children with large local reactions, although an exception may be made for those who live in heavily infested areas. There is also an increased risk of systemic allergic reactions to future stings in children who have cutaneous manifestations after getting stung. This makes many experts put some children on fire ant venom immunotherapy, while others do not.<ref name="Pesek_Lockey_2013"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Freeman|first1=T.M.|title=Hypersensitivity to Hymenoptera stings|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|date=2004|volume=351|issue=19|pages=1978–1984|doi=10.1056/NEJMcp042013|pmid=15525723}}</ref>
The recommended maintenance dose is between 0.5 mL of a 1:100 w/v 1:10 w/v WBE.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moffitt|first1=J.E. |last2=Golden|first2=D.B.K.|last3=Reisman|first3=R.E. |last4=Lee|first4=R.|last5=Nicklas|first5=R. |last6=Freeman|first6=T.|last7=deShazo |first7=R.|last8=Tracy|first8=J.|last9=Bernstein|first9=I.L.|last10=Blessing-Moore|first10=J. |title=Stinging insect hypersensitivity: A practice parameter update |journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=2004 |volume=114|issue=4|pages=869–886 |doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2004.07.046 |pmid=15480329}}</ref> For fire ant venom immunotherapy, the most common maintenance dose is 0.5 mL of a 1:200 (wt/vol) dilution.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haymore|first1=B.R.|last2=McCoy|first2=R. L.|last3=Nelson|first3=M.R.|title=Imported fire ant immunotherapy prescribing patterns in a large health care system during a 17-year period|journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology|date=2009|volume=102|issue=5|pages=422–425 |doi=10.1016/S1081-1206(10)60515-7 |pmid=19492665}}</ref> During the build-up phase, it is recommended that dosing is given weekly or biweekly, although some scientists suggest that rush protocols can be successful.<ref name="Pesek_Lockey_2013"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tankersley|first1=M.S. |last2=Walker|first2=R.L.|last3=Butler |first3=W.K.|last4=Hagan |first4=L.L. |last5=Napoli|first5=D.C.|last6=Freeman|first6=T.M.|title=Safety and efficacy of an imported fire ant rush immunotherapy protocol with and without prophylactic treatment|journal=The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=2002|volume=109|issue=3|pages=556–562|pmid=11898006|doi=10.1067/mai.2002.121956}}</ref> It is recommended that patients going through immunotherapy receive treatment for three to five years, and lifelong therapy, although there is no consensus as to how long an individual should be treated.<ref name="Pesek_Lockey_2013"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Golden|first1=D.B.K. |last2=Moffitt|first2=J.|last3=Nicklas |first3=R.A.|last4=Freeman|first4=T. |last5=Graft|first5=D.F.|last6=Reisman |first6=R.E.|last7=Tracy |first7=J.M. |last8=Bernstein|first8=D.|last9=Blessing-Moore|first9=J.|last10=Cox|first10=L.|last11=Khan|first11=D.A.|last12=Lang |first12=D.M.|last13=Oppenheimer|first13=J.|last14=Portnoy|first14=J.M.|last15=Randolph|first15=C.|last16=Schuller|first16=D.E.|last17=Spector|first17=S.L.|last18=Tilles|first18=S.A.|last19=Wallace|first19=D.|title=Stinging insect hypersensitivity: A practice parameter update 2011|journal=Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=2011 |volume=127|issue=4|pages=852–854.e23|doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2011.01.025|pmid=21458655}}</ref>
==Stings to animals==
The stings of the red imported fire ant in animals are painful, and may prove life-threatening.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Prahlow |first1=Joseph A. |last2=Barnard |first2=Jeffrey J. |title=Fatal Anaphylaxis Due to Fire Ant Stings |journal=The American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology |date=June 1998 |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=137–142 |doi=10.1097/00000433-199806000-00007}}</ref> In dogs, stings from the red imported fire ant can cause pustular [[Cutaneous condition|dermatosis]], a condition where [[pustule]]s appear in crops as a result of the ant sting.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Conceição|first1=L.G.|last2=Haddad|first2=V. Jr.|last3=Loures|first3=F.H.|title=Pustular dermatosis caused by fire ant (''Solenopsis invicta'') stings in a dog|journal=Veterinary Dermatology|date=2006|volume=17|issue=6|pages=453–455|pmid=17083579|doi=10.1111/j.1365-3164.2006.00555.x}}</ref> After getting stung, the immediate response consists of [[erythema]] and swelling. The pustules remain for approximately 24 hours, whereas in humans they can last for several days.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rakich|first1=P.M.|last2=Latimer |first2=K.S.|last3=Mispagel |first3=M.E.|last4=Steffens |first4=W.L. |title=Clinical and histologic characterization of cutaneous reactions to stings of the imported fire ant (''Solenopsis invicta'') in dogs |journal=Veterinary Pathology|date=1993 |volume=30|issue=6|pages=555–559 |doi=10.1177/030098589303000609|pmid=8116149}}</ref> In livestock, red imported ants mostly sting animals in regions with no hair, particularly around the ears, eyes, muzzle, the [[perineum]] and ventral portion of the abdomen. Newborn or young livestock can be blinded or killed when attacked by the ants.<ref name="Drees_et_al_2002">{{cite web|last1=Drees|first1=B.M.|last2=Jensen|first2=J.M. |last3=Joyce|first3=J.R.|last4=Barr|first4=C.L. |last5=Reagor|first5=J.C.|title=Diagnosing and treating animals for red imported fire ant injury|url=http://fireant.tamu.edu/files/2013/02/FAPFS022.2002rev.pdf|work=Texas Imported Fire Ant Research and Management Project|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=30 March 2016|date=2002}}</ref>{{sfn|Capinera|2008|p=189}} Healthy individuals are less likely to be attacked than weak or sick animals. Red [[papule]] and mild swelling occur, followed by vesicopustule with a red halo developing within 24 to 48 hours. The eyes and eyelids are commonly damaged from the stings; in sheep and goats, ophthalmic ointment containing antibiotics and corticosteroids can be used to treat the eyes of sheep and goats, but this treatment is not recommended for horses. In non-domestic animals, cases of red imported fire ants stings in animals such as ferrets, moles squirrels, white-tailed deer, cottontail rabbits, and newborn blackbucks have been reported, as well as lizards and screech owl nestlings. The aftermath of the injuries is like those in domestic animals.<ref name="Drees_et_al_2002"/>
Red imported fire ants are known to actively kill vertebrate animals, and cause significant livestock losses.<ref>Adams, C.T. (1986) Agricultural and medical impact of the imported fire ants. In: Lofgren, C.S. and Vander Meer, R.K. (eds) Fire Ants and Leq.fcutting Ants: Biology and Management. Westview Press, Boulder, Colorado, pp. 48-57.</ref> Animals may trigger major stinging episodes when they disturb active nests, with thousands of ants participating in the attack. During such episodes an animal may suffer from hundreds to thousands of individual stings. It is suspected that many victims of the red imported fire ants may be [[Animal psychopathology#Depression|depressed]] as a result of the effects of the toxin. Some animals may swallow red imported fire ants as they lick or bite around the sites they are stinging. This can cause additional injuries inside the animal itself, especially in the upper gastrointestinal tract. In suckling white tail deer fawns, sting sites have been found in the oesophagus and [[abomasum]]; toxins from the ingested ants may cause inflammation of the gastrointestinal lining.<ref name="Drees_et_al_2002"/>

'''VISQ''' (Portuguese acronym for "Variables that Interact Semi-Quantitatively") is a scientific-educational [[software]] developed using [[Carnegie-Mellon]]'s [[Vpython#History|cT]], in the year of 1993 by M. Thielo (as a [[physics]] undergrad at the time), based on Jon Ogborn ideas for semi-quantitative modeling of [[dynamical systems]], for both [[MS-DOS]] and [[Macintosh]] systems (in 2012 the author published a new, Windows compatible version). Awarded by the [[Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul]] (UFRGS) in 1994, the system is based on the theory of continuous [[neural networks]], and have been used in many research projects since then, mainly in Master and Doctoral Dissertations in the area of [[environmental education]]. An introduction to VISQ (in Portuguese) can be found at the university site,<ref>[http://www.modelciencias.furg.br/bin/ferramentas/semi/visq.php VISQ: and introduction to semiquantitative modelling tools (in Portuguese)]</ref> and the [[software]] can be freely downloaded from the author's site<ref>[http://www.if.ufrgs.br/~thielo/visqw12.zip Downloading VISQ for Windows]</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.if.ufrgs.br/~thielo/visq.zip] Download MS-DOS Version of VISQ *[http://www.modelciencias.furg.br/profecomp/imanvis.htm] Reference manual (English) *[http://www.modelciencias.furg.br/bin/ferramentas/semi/visq.php] Representing Semiquantitative Variables with VISQ (in Portuguese) *[http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119171348/abstract] Journal Article containing a case study with the program, published in the International Journal of Computer Assisted Learning *[http://www.fisica.furg.br/profecomp/artigos/MSET99.pdf] Article published in the annals of the Mathematics/Science Education and Technology conference(M/SET 99) *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwJq_U22d74] Animated example of a semiquantitative model running in VISQ.

{{unreferenced|date=September 2014}} [[File:Cartuja1.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The Valldemossa Charterhouse]] [[File:Cartuja kartäuserkloster2.JPG|thumb|Tower]] The '''Valldemossa Charterhouse''' (Catalan: ''Cartoixa de Valldemossa'', Spanish: ''Cartuja de Valldemosa''), translatable as: Carthusian Monastery of Valldemossa) is a palace in [[Valldemossa]], [[Majorca]] that was residence of the king [[Sancho of Majorca]] former royal residence and Royal [[Charterhouse (monastery)|Charterhouse]] (15th century).
== History == The origin of the complex dates back to the time of King [[James II of Majorca]], who chose this exceptional place in the [[Sierra de Tramuntana]], located more than 400 meters high, to build a palace for his son Sancho, known as the "Palace of the King Sancho". In the year 1399 [[Martin of Aragon]] yielded all the royal possessions of Valldemossa to the [[Carthusian]] friars. These founded the Charterhouse and inhabited it until 1835, when it happened to private hands by the [[Spanish confiscation|Ecclesiastical confiscations of Mendizábal]].
The church, a neoclassical building decorated by great artists and craftsmen of the time, began to be built in 1751 on the primitive church erected in 1446. The complex has a cloister -one of the oldest parts of the current buildings-, the old pharmacy of the Carthusians, garden and the rooms of the Prioral Cell-chapel, former library, audience room, bedroom ...- where the historical and artistic legacy of the Carthusians is preserved, showing how the monks lived. In the cells there are the documents and memories of the stay of the musician [[Frédéric Chopin]] and the writer [[George Sand]] the winter of the years 1838-1839. In the cell 4 Chopin composed his '' [[Preludes (Chopin)|Preludes Op. 28]]'' and Sand wrote ''[[A Winter in Majorca]]''.

'''Weiser Antiquarian Books''' is the oldest occult bookstore in the United States. It specialises in books on Aleister Crowley and his circle, magic, mysticism, eastern religions and alternative spirituality. Its earlier New York incarnation, The Weiser Bookshop, was described by Leslie A. Shepherd as "perhaps the most famous occult bookstore in the U.S."<ref>Leslie Shepherd, Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology, 2nd Printing, Detroit, Michigan: Gale Research Company. Vol. 2, p. 978.</ref>
==Early years== The original Samuel Weiser Bookstore was started in New York City's famous "[[Book Row]]" area by Samuel Weiser in 1926. It moved several times within the "Book Row" before relocating to 117 4th Avenue, where it remained for a number of decades.<ref>(Anon) International Directory For Antiquarian Booksellers 1958, Zurich: ILAB, 1958.</ref> To start with Samuel Weiser Books sold general used books, but with an emphasis on the occult and comparative religion. In 1949 Samuel Weiser was joined by his brother Ben who had worked with him for a few years in the 1930s. Throughout the 1950s and 1960s they increased Weiser Books' specialist focus on the occult at a time when many bookstores refused to handle such subjects.
One of the customers of the shop was [[Karl Germer]], successor to [[Aleister Crowley]] as head of the [[Ordo Templi Orientis]]. After Crowley's death, most of his papers and other possessions were shipped to Germer including the unbound sheets of the 1937 edition of his book ''The Equinox of the Gods''. In 1955 Germer sold the sheets to Samuel Weiser who had them bound up in maroon cloth and sold through the shop. This was probably one of the first books to be published by Samuel Weiser – although it retained the original O.T.O. title page and imprint.<ref>Details of the printing history of the Germer / Weiser issue of ''The Equinox of the Gods'' are given in {{cite web | title = Weiser Antiquarian Books Catalog # 10. Aleister Crowley: Books, Ephemera & A Drawing | url = http://www.weiserantiquarian.com/catalogten/ | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090105225650/http://www.weiserantiquarian.com/catalogten | archivedate = 5 January 2009 | publisher = Weiser Antiquarian Books | date = 17 November 2006}}</ref> Germer also sold Weiser a collection of the First Edition of Crowley's masterwork on the tarot, ''The Book of Thoth''. Despite being leather bound, printed on handmade paper, and in an edition of only 200 copies signed by Crowley himself, interest in "the Beast" was low at the time and for nearly two decades copies could be purchased from the shop for $50 or less (as of 2009, they command thousands of dollars).
Rising rents and urban change forced many of the bookstores out of "Book Row." A number moved into the adjacent Broadway, with Weiser, whose stock had now grown to over a hundred thousand volumes, taking a premises at 845 Broadway. The new building had a huge basement, which the Weiser brothers crammed with books on all manner of subjects. After a heart attack forced Samuel Weiser into semi-retirement, Ben Weiser was joined by Samuel's son Donald.<ref>Marvin Mondlin and Roy Meador, "Book Row, an Anecdotal and Pictorial History of the Antiquarian Book Trade," Foreword by [[Madeleine B. Stern]]. Carroll & Graf Publishers, New York, 2004, pp. 99-100.</ref>
==The 1960s onwards == Samuel Weiser had begun publishing in the mid-1950s, and through the late 1950s produced a small number of books under the Occult Research Press imprint before starting to publish under his own name. The development of the 1960s "counter-culture," and the growth of popular interest in esotericism and Eastern religious and mystical traditions, allowed Ben and Donald Weiser to expand the company's publishing activities. They recruited many contemporary authors, such as Israel Regardie, who were customers. The shop's stock also provided them with rare and out-of-print books that they could reprint.
The late 1960s saw the bookstore go through another move, this time into two floors at 734 Broadway, not far from Astor Place.<ref>Kenneth T. Jackson (Editor). "The Encyclopedia of New York City," New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005.</ref> The move gave Donald Weiser, who now ran the business with the assistance of Fred Mendel, the chance to further increase their specialisation. In addition to used and rare books on the occult, Weiser Books, or "The Weiser Bookstore" as it was then known, also stocked new domestic and imported titles. The publishing side of the business was also expanded, and moved into its own premises at 625 Broadway.<ref>Marvin Mondlin and Roy Meador, "Book Row, an Anecdotal and Pictorial History of the Antiquarian Book Trade," p. 100.</ref>
By the early 1980s the costs of maintaining a number of businesses in New York City had grown increasingly difficult to sustain, and Donald Weiser moved Samuel Weiser Publishing and the new book distribution wing of the company to York, Maine.
In 1985 he also moved the specialist rare books section of the company, now named Weiser Antiquarian Books, to York, where it shared a two storey warehouse with the publishing company's distribution centre. Much to the dismay of its many New York city customers, soaring city rents brought about the closure of the Broadway store in the early 1990s. Its huge stock of books was packed into shipping containers and moved to the new location in Maine, to be added to the stock of Weiser Antiquarian Books.
In the year 2000 Donald Weiser sold the publishing division of the company. Its new owners renamed it [[Red Wheel Weiser Conari|Red Wheel / Weiser]] but kept its York premises until 2006, when they moved the publishing company's editorial department to San Francisco and its marketing department to Newburyport, Massachusetts.{{cn|date=December 2011}}
In 2005 Donald Weiser retired, and Weiser Antiquarian Books was purchased by its then-director Marilyn Rinn, and Australian writer and bookseller, Keith Richmond. The following year they moved the company to its current premises in Cape Neddick Maine: a one-time art gallery for American artist Walt Kuhn, which had more recently been the headquarters of Samuel Weiser Publishing. In 2007 they also began publishing under the Teitan Press imprint which was founded by Martin P. Starr and Frank Winston.
==Catalogs== For decades the Weiser Bookstore issued printed catalogs that listed anywhere between a few hundred and several thousand items, with basic descriptions of the book's author, title, condition and price. The advent of the internet brought an end to these printed catalogs, and for some years Weiser Antiquarian Books only listed its books on various internet book-sites and directly on to its own website.
In January 2006, Weiser Antiquarian Books began issuing a new series of on-line catalogs. Most of these catalogs are devoted to a specific author or theme. A large number have been devoted to the works of [[Aleister Crowley]] (in whom the store specialises), as well as authors including [[Dion Fortune]], [[Israel Regardie]], [[John Dee]] and [[Austin Osman Spare]]. In a number of cases – such as their catalogs on [[John Whiteside Parsons|Jack Parsons]], [[Marcelo Ramos Motta]] and [[Kenneth Grant]] – these are the first{{cn|date=December 2011}} bookseller catalogs devoted specifically to these authors. Other catalogs have been devoted to specific journals - notably ''[[The Occult Review]]'', ''The Inner Light'', and ''Ambix'', - and subjects such as [[alchemy]], [[spiritualism]], [[Hermetica]], [[Hermetic Qabalah]], [[Magick (Aleister Crowley)|magick]], The [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]] and [[Rosicrucianism]]. Others have been devoted to books from specific collections: for example those of Helen Parsons Smith, Ray Burlingame, Edward Noel FitzGerald and Jean Michaud, or to collections of documents such as the [[Karl Germer]] / Reea Leffingwell correspondence<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weiserantiquarian.com/catalogsevensupplement/ |title=Weiser Antiquarian Books - Supplement to Catalog # 7. 'Fraternally Yours, Karl' |archivedate=December 8, 2008 |publisher=Weiser Antiquarian Books |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208100524/http://weiserantiquarian.com/catalogsevensupplement/ }}</ref> or the C. F. Russell / Sydney Hamilton French / G∴B∴G∴ archive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weiserantiquarian.com/catalogfiftythree/ |title=Weiser Antiquarian Books Catalog # 53. 'Aleister Crowley, Victor Neuburg & Friends.' |archivedate=April 15, 2010 |publisher=Weiser Antiquarian Books |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100415012808/http://weiserantiquarian.com/catalogfiftythree/ }}</ref>
The catalogs contain bibliographical, historical and biographical information about the books offered for sale, and often detail previously unpublished manuscript and other material. They are often cited by researchers in on-line and printed publications.<ref>A number of Weiser Antiquarian listings have, for example, been adapted (with permission) by bibliographer Alan Pritchard for use in his online bibliography of Alchemy: {{cite web | url = http://www.alchemy-bibliography.co.uk/ | work = Alchemy: a bibliography of English-language writings | title = Using the Bibliography | first = Alan | last = Pritchard | date = 27 May 2007}}</ref> At the request of customers and researchers, the older catalogs are now kept in an online archive.<ref>{{cite web|author=Weiser Antiquarian Books |url=http://weiserantiquarian.com/catalogarchivepage/ |title=Weiser Antiquarian Books - Catalogue Archive Page |publisher=Weiser Antiquarian Books |date= |accessdate=2012-03-04}}</ref>
Weiser Antiquarian Books is now primarily an internet retailer, and does not maintain an open shop, but is open to established customers by prior appointment.
